summary: One time I was talking to my friend and we were like "RDJ is literally Tony Stark" and then this girl turns around and goes, "no...
body:
One time I was talking to my friend and we were like “RDJ is literally Tony Stark” and then this girl turns around and goes, “no he’s not, he’s gotten way more rolls than Tony Stark, that’s not all he is” and I just feel like, she missed the point. Like obviously he had other preformances he’s done an amazing job at, but like, as things are playing out, like, it’s obvious that RDJ’s role as Tony Stark was special and specifically different, he loved his character so much. Like he’s is literally dedicating the next 11 years(? Correct me if I’m wrong) to helping to save the planet.

Also, not to mention that the casting (shoutout to Sarah Finn) it’s is perfect we are supposed to kinda think, wow, like, they are that character is some way shape or form, or are able to play them exactly as they are meant to be played.

I guess I shouldn’t be this bothered by the comment, but, like, I don’t know, I’ve been thinking about it for a while. Tony Stark loves in RDJ, and I guess it sort of bothered me that like, someone would take that offensively?? Like, it’s complement, he obviously not exactly like him, but it just shows how much he brings to the character. Just think about all the lines he improvises. That’s a true representation of how well he know his character. Like, when they wanted him to apologise to Steve, and RDJ knew that Tony wouldn’t have felt that way, so he did the EXACT OPPOSITE. All because he know that character that well.

summary: #21 if you’re still doing the prompts??  😁
question: #21 if you’re still doing the prompts??  😁
answer:
Here you go! Thank you for this! xx. - MJ


Peter was staring down the barrel of a gun.

That’s when it dawned on him, oh, oh yeah, I am neck deep in shit.

See, no matter which way he swung this, he’d still get his ass handed to him on a silver platter. If not by this gunman then by Aunt May or Tony; whichever one got to him first. It was hours passed his curfew but he was awakened by the police scanner beside his bed, reporting a jewelry store heist happening only a few blocks over. Queens was sizable city and a robbery was happening only a few blocks from where he lived. How could he not go? Aunt May couldn’t possibly get mad at him for doing his job. It was only 2 AM and he’d only be around the corner. Come on, that was pure Spider-Man luck.

It turned out the sensation he thought was luck was apparently indigestion from Aunt May’s meatloaf because so far nothing was going his way. Two armed thieves had been webbed up but the third had ran leaving him alone with one.

“I’m bulletproof,” Peter began, throwing his hands in the air. “But please, don’t shoot me.” The suit was bulletproof, sure, but that didn’t mean getting shot wouldn’t still hurt like hell. There was still flesh under all that nanotechnology. How would he explain bullet indentations to Mr. Stark?

The gunman smiled behind the ski mask, trailing the gun from his head and to his chest.

“I will kill you.” He cocked the gun. “And history can decide whether I am the hero or the villain.”

Peter shuddered. That sounded like something out of a James Bond movie. It would be kind of cool, if, y’know, he didn’t have a gun aimed at his chest.

“Yeahyeahyeah, cool, cool, cool. I hear you, I do. But listen, I just had this suit dry cleaned and it would be a shame if you scuffed it with your bullets. So can we skip all the shooty-shooty stuff and jump to where I arrest you and then disappear into the sunrise?” Peter slowly began tip backwards out of the door frame where the glass had been shattered. Faintly, in the distance, he could hear sirens nearing and behind him repulsors cut out and metal crunched the concrete behind him. Oh no. Papa Bear Stark was on the scene.

Suddenly, the gun was no longer trained on him but on the figure behind him. Immediately, bullets began to rain around him; the cacophonous ping! of metal bouncing off of metal filling the sleeping city.

“Get behind me, Peter!” Wait…that was…Peter spared a glance over his shoulder. “Uncle Colonel Rhodes?” Peter immediately dove behind the commander. “What are you doing here, sir?”

“Saving your ass, kid, Outta my way.” War Machine stepped around Peter. Within seconds, the gunman was unarmed, cuffed and being guided to the police car out front. Hey, he could’ve done that!

The fly back to Tower was mostly silence, aside from Peter’s occasional protests that he wasn’t injured and he preferred to sneak back into his apartment and go to bed before school tomorrow.

“Nope, Tony requested that he see you personally.” Any other day, Peter would’ve burst open like a pinata of joy under any other circumstance but he just felt throat constrict with panic. They landed outside on the launching pad, starting for the sliding doors.

“But I had it under control, Mr. Rhodes, sir! I mean, you saw! The dude with the gun was all like ‘I’ll make you pay, blargh!’ and I was like ‘Stop! I’m Spider-Man!’ And then, then you came in! You were like ‘I’ve come to steal your thunder, Parker.’ Then the gun dude started shooting, all like bratatata! Pshhew! Vvvvrr--” Rhodey clapped a hand on Peter’s shoulder.

“Yeah Peter, I was there.” Rhodey disengaged the suit and tugged off Peter’s mask. “I know what happened.”

“It sounds like it was a blast!” Peter whirled to his left where Tony was leaning against the door frame, clapping slowly. “Real bang-up job, kid.” Tony sauntered forwards, clapping a hand on James’ shoulders. “Thanks, Rhodey. I got it from here.”

Colonel nodded and cast a bleak glance at Peter before walking inside.

“Mr. Stark! I was fine and I had everything under control–”

“Pipe down, Minnie Mouse. I don’t want to hear it.”

“But Mr. St–”

“Can it, Squirt!” Peter blinked. It was rare that Tony ever raised his voice but it got the job done. Shocked and wide eyed, Peter stood at attention. “Riddle me this, Superman. How does a superhero protect his country, his state– his neighborhood, if he’s dead?”

Peter swallowed audibly. It was a rhetorical but Tony seemed to be waiting for an answer. “He can’t.”

“That’s right. He can’t. You can’t be a friendly neighborhood Spider-Man if you let someone use you as target practice.” Tony ran a hand over his face. “Peter, the 5-0 handle things like this. Theft, vandalism, murder. That’s stuff for the civilians. You need to learn to gauge the urgency of a situation. Walk little old ladies across the street, and save kittens from trees. But don’t walk into gunfire! You have to stop putting your life on the line unnecessarily! You need to stop putting your life on the line, period!”

“Well, where were you, Mr. Stark?” Peter’s voice rose out of him without much thought. “Huh? Where were you then?”

“At home! Just like you should’ve been. I was home with one of my children, praying that my other one made it back safely! Oh, and trying to calm your aunt, who you scared the shit out of, mind you.” Tony jabbed a thumb over his shoulder and Peter looked inside. In the doorway, stood Aunt May in her pajamas, holding his police radio. Oh shit. “So next time you think it’ll be fun to go dance the tango with an armed criminal, please, give someone a warning first.”

The silence hung thickly between the two of them. Peter broke first, hanging his head.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know you are, but go tell that to your aunt.” Tony tugged Peter into a hug. “I’m glad you’re home.”

Peter let out a breath he didn’t know he was holding.

“I’ll go talk to May.”

“You’re gonna be grounded until you’re 30, I can tell you that.” Tony snickered.

Peter winced. Yeah, he had seen that coming.

“Oh goodie.”

“It sounds like it was a blast!” Peter whirled to his left where Tony was leaning against the door frame, clapping slowly. “Real bang-up job, kid.” Tony sauntered forwards, clapping a hand on James’ shoulders. “Thanks, Rhodey. I got it from here.”

Colonel nodded and cast a bleak glance at Peter before walking inside.

“Mr. Stark! I was fine and I had everything under control–”

“Pipe down, Minnie Mouse. I don’t want to hear it.”

“But Mr. St–”

“Can it, Squirt!” Peter blinked. It was rare that Tony ever raised his voice but it got the job done. Shocked and wide eyed, Peter stood at attention. “Riddle me this, Superman. How does a superhero protect his country, his state– his neighborhood, if he’s dead?”

Peter swallowed audibly. It was a rhetorical but Tony seemed to be waiting for an answer. “He can’t.”

“That’s right. He can’t. You can’t be a friendly neighborhood Spider-Man if you let someone use you as target practice.” Tony ran a hand over his face. “Peter, the 5-0 handle things like this. Theft, vandalism, murder. That’s stuff for the civilians. You need to learn to gauge the urgency of a situation. Walk little old ladies across the street, and save kittens from trees. But don’t walk into gunfire! You have to stop putting your life on the line unnecessarily! You need to stop putting your life on the line, period!”

“Well, where were you, Mr. Stark?” Peter’s voice rose out of him without much thought. “Huh? Where were you then?”

“At home! Just like you should’ve been. I was home with one of my children, praying that my other one made it back safely! Oh, and trying to calm your aunt, who you scared the shit out of, mind you.” Tony jabbed a thumb over his shoulder and Peter looked inside. In the doorway, stood Aunt May in her pajamas, holding his police radio. Oh shit. “So next time you think it’ll be fun to go dance the tango with an armed criminal, please, give someone a warning first.”

The silence hung thickly between the two of them. Peter broke first, hanging his head.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know you are, but go tell that to your aunt.” Tony tugged Peter into a hug. “I’m glad you’re home.”

Peter let out a breath he didn’t know he was holding.

“I’ll go talk to May.”

“You’re gonna be grounded until you’re 30, I can tell you that.” Tony snickered.

Peter winced. Yeah, he had seen that coming.

“Oh goodie.”

title: All Worth It For You 1/?
body:
Where did he go wrong?

A cloud of glimmering silver bubbles raced past him to the surface. His world, once clear and vibrant with a plethora of colors and sounds, was now darkening with the color blue, a monotonous pounding ruthlessly crashing into his head.

Steve’s orders were clear. He was to infiltrate a GAIA ship and disable its communications. Incapacitate all enemies. Gather intel for SHIELD review. Leave. Debrief.

Green-gold scales filled his vision, a tail twirling and flicking with minimal effort. The vice grip on his legs grew tighter. Pain flared just above his ankles; the merman’s claws dug deep into his skin, constantly slicing his flesh with each movement of his tail.

Steve expected to be intercepted at any time. It’s happened before, it’ll happen again. He did not expect a man to slam him over the railing of the ship and plunge in after him. Steve had lashed out with his shield, the metal slicing through the water, but it hit nothing. He kicked, again and again, but the sharp hands always returned.

The merman yanked him downwards with such force that bubbles shot out of Steve’s mouth; in an instant a clawed hand wrapped itself around his throat. Pain exploded behind his eyes when the man slammed Steve’s head against the sandy floor.

“You’ve become unbelievably annoying, Captain.” The merman’s voice rang clear in the blue. His name was Ross Sweinden, Steve remembered, one of GAIA’s packs of muscle. They had met before, only a week ago, when Ross had nearly bested him in combat. Steve was impressed, he respected Ross’s strength; the man would’ve made a worthy Avenger if only he wasn’t so eager to use brute force. “How’s about we end this?”

Steve didn’t bother to reply as his fingers twitched, aching to remove the oppressive hand. His vision was darkening, a black fuzz consuming his world. Water forced itself into his mouth, down into his lungs. A tight burn in his throat chest contrasted the chill of the blue void around him.

Ross shook him. "Don’t die on me, Steve!” His grip on Steve’s neck tightened—and then loosened.

Steve didn’t have the energy to wonder why. The black fuzz was now invading his mind, peaceful and comforting and urging him to just let go, you’ve lived long enough, Peggy is waiting, you’ve got a date. Yes, he’s given his all to this era, hasn’t he? He built up the Avengers, stopped an alien invasion, and found and liberated his friend. What more could the world, could SHIELD, want from him?

The Avengers will survive. They will take care of everyone.

Let go, Steve.

Blue filled his vision again, unusually bright. Although Steve’s vision was blurred with pain—head injury, he had to remain awake—he saw that a face was before him. It wasn’t Ross; no, a dark-haired man stared at him, a sharp-toothed but relieved smile on his face.

Steve couldn’t tear his gaze from the merman’s eyes. His irises and pupils were glowing the same blue that shined out from his strange metal suit. The werewolf was transfixed.

Too soon a smooth, featureless mask slid down over the merman’s face. He turned to the left and, his voice hosting a mechanical undertone, clicked and whistled at a companion.

In a similar mechanical suit—this one black and silver and glowing orange—was his friend. Whether it was a machine or a merperson in a metal shell, they easily and repeatedly overpowered Ross. The GAIA agent snarled and swiped but he knew he was outmatched. When the orange merman glanced at Blue, he swung in place and bolted away.

Steve really wouldn’t be surprised if Ross was the type to swear revenge.

Blue and orange, gray and black, filled his vision. Unnaturally smooth fingers and arms wrapped themselves around the joint connecting his arms to his shoulders and hoisted him up with a gentleness he only recieved from Natasha.

Above him was the moon, its form wavering erratically. Werewolves and the Moon, people thought the two had a connection. Dr. Erskine never mentioned the effects the moon had on werewolves or even human-turned-werewolves, and Steve never felt any more powerful under a full moon than he did under a crescent moon. But he prayed anyway, begging whatever—if anything—possessed the moon to heal the concussion he knew he’d have, that it wouldn’t last too long, that he’d get to go back to the surface, that Natasha and the others search for him.

_____________________________________________


Tony knew his father hated humans. Something about a human male chasing him when he was a pup. So when—and it is a when, because Father had his ways of worming secrets from their holders—Tony’s big Star was found…well, the young Princes will ensure he gets sent to the wealthiest quadrant in the human community.

For the sixth time in their hold, Star went limp. A concussion. Tony knew what those were like, to fall unconscious again and again, to sometimes forget what happened, to have the life sucked out of you at the mere flick of a tail—or leg, in Star’s case. All he and Arno could do was swim as fast as they can to Strange’s Sanctum and keep him as still as possible in their arms.

“He’s different, this Star of yours,” Arno warbled.

Tony nodded. Even in the water, humans had a particular scent to them. But Star’s taste was warped, human but not-human. “So how deep do we need to bury this secret?” Because if Father found Star he’ll know immediately that Star is in some way special, and he’ll have him tested. And if there was anything Father loved more than his own sons, it was prestige and the admiration (coughjealousycough) that came with it.

“Pretend-he-doesn’t-exist deep.” Arno led them in a dive though a cavern filled with shrimp and spiders.

“Ah, my weakness.” But Tony heard the implication in his brother’s words: We should’ve stayed home. But that only hardened Tony’s resolve to help and protect the not-human. There was something about him that lured Tony to him, something that Tony knew would be worth the hell Father will eventually put him through. As they emerged into the depths again, Tony spared Star a glance. His head was up, turning left and right as they passed swarms of bioluminescent jellyfish, but his movements were sluggish.

In the distance were the upper shelves of the Subduon, the trench Eingara was built in: the shelves of the poor, of the merchants and traders and artisans, and of the Upper Military. Piercing through the encompassing darkness were the lights, glittering and flashing red, blue, green, and yellow. The Sanctum was more attuned to the wealthy while still remaining quite a swim away; it was located right at the bottom of the trench.

“There’re going to be a lot of curious fish,” warned the elder of the brothers, angling them toward the bright lights. His gray face plate lifted, revealing a thoughtful frown. “Star still needs time to acclimate. If we take him down there, we’ll have another flounder.”

Tony nodded, lifting his own face plate. When they were young there was news of a Merrow who’d saved a human and brought them down to the depths. But even with the newfound abilities to breathe underwater and survive its bone-reaching chill, the human still had yet to adapt to the crushing depths. By the time the Merrow reached bottom of the trench, the human “looked more like a flounder.”

And Tony did not want to be the traumatized owner of a flounder.

There was a human community up on the shelf, high enough that Star would not succumb to the pressure. For now, they were Star’s best chance at survival.
As if they were sharks on the prowl the civilians cleared the way for their princes as they swept through the city, their eyes lingering on the limp not-human in their grasp. They hummed and clicked theories to one another but none were arrogant enough to intercept them. Tony prayed that they couldn’t catch Star’s scent in the water, prayed that a noble adorned with peridot, gold, and/or a rainbow of pearls wouldn’t be in the crowd.

The human living area was a time capsule, a timeline of trends that dominated the stonemasonry field mixed with the myriad of surface cultures. The first humans, chosen survivors from shipwrecks throughout the centuries, were dumped in towns of jagged and shoddy stonework. Generations passed, and new divisions were added, the stonework displaying floral and animal reliefs as well as strange geometric depictions.

Displaying a mixture of whale and dolphin reliefs and curving lines was the hospital, one of the largest buildings in western division. Like the Merrow civilians, the humans threw themselves out the way of the royals, signing to one another and pointing to Star.

Clusters of pillar coral lights bathed the inside of the reception area with kelp yellows and sky blues. The receptionist, an elderly woman, lifted her head as the princes swam up to her. Seeing that their load was limp, her eyes widened and she thrust herself from the desk. The woman pointed to a white-lit hallway on her right and swam off.

Tony and Arno followed.

The room the receptionist led them to was lit with a golden coral light that was growing downwards from the ceiling. The stony floor was carpeted with sea grass and the walls swayed with vibrant anemones and soft corals. To the left of the doorway was a wall-long counter, all its contents sorted into neat groups. In the middle of the room was a mechanical bed fashioned into a mussel shell, fitted with sealskin sheets. The princes lay Star down on the sheets, settling him on his belly.

Star blinked open his eyes. Those little windows to the sky searched the room before fixating on Tony. Confusion was written all over his youthful face.

“You’ll be safe here, I promise,” Tony assured.

“There’re going to be a lot of curious fish,” warned the elder of the brothers, angling them toward the bright lights. His gray face plate lifted, revealing a thoughtful frown. “Star still needs time to acclimate. If we take him down there, we’ll have another flounder.”

Tony nodded, lifting his own face plate. When they were young there was news of a Merrow who’d saved a human and brought them down to the depths. But even with the newfound abilities to breathe underwater and survive its bone-reaching chill, the human still had yet to adapt to the crushing depths. By the time the Merrow reached bottom of the trench, the human “looked more like a flounder.”

And Tony did not want to be the traumatized owner of a flounder.

There was a human community up on the shelf, high enough that Star would not succumb to the pressure. For now, they were Star’s best chance at survival.
As if they were sharks on the prowl the civilians cleared the way for their princes as they swept through the city, their eyes lingering on the limp not-human in their grasp. They hummed and clicked theories to one another but none were arrogant enough to intercept them. Tony prayed that they couldn’t catch Star’s scent in the water, prayed that a noble adorned with peridot, gold, and/or a rainbow of pearls wouldn’t be in the crowd.

The human living area was a time capsule, a timeline of trends that dominated the stonemasonry field mixed with the myriad of surface cultures. The first humans, chosen survivors from shipwrecks throughout the centuries, were dumped in towns of jagged and shoddy stonework. Generations passed, and new divisions were added, the stonework displaying floral and animal reliefs as well as strange geometric depictions.

Displaying a mixture of whale and dolphin reliefs and curving lines was the hospital, one of the largest buildings in western division. Like the Merrow civilians, the humans threw themselves out the way of the royals, signing to one another and pointing to Star.

Clusters of pillar coral lights bathed the inside of the reception area with kelp yellows and sky blues. The receptionist, an elderly woman, lifted her head as the princes swam up to her. Seeing that their load was limp, her eyes widened and she thrust herself from the desk. The woman pointed to a white-lit hallway on her right and swam off.

Tony and Arno followed.

The room the receptionist led them to was lit with a golden coral light that was growing downwards from the ceiling. The stony floor was carpeted with sea grass and the walls swayed with vibrant anemones and soft corals. To the left of the doorway was a wall-long counter, all its contents sorted into neat groups. In the middle of the room was a mechanical bed fashioned into a mussel shell, fitted with sealskin sheets. The princes lay Star down on the sheets, settling him on his belly.

Star blinked open his eyes. Those little windows to the sky searched the room before fixating on Tony. Confusion was written all over his youthful face.

“You’ll be safe here, I promise,” Tony assured.

trail.content_raw:
Where did he go wrong?

A cloud of glimmering silver bubbles raced past him to the surface. His world, once clear and vibrant with a plethora of colors and sounds, was now darkening with the color blue, a monotonous pounding ruthlessly crashing into his head.

Steve’s orders were clear. He was to infiltrate a GAIA ship and disable its communications. Incapacitate all enemies. Gather intel for SHIELD review. Leave. Debrief.

Green-gold scales filled his vision, a tail twirling and flicking with minimal effort. The vice grip on his legs grew tighter. Pain flared just above his ankles; the merman’s claws dug deep into his skin, constantly slicing his flesh with each movement of his tail.

Steve expected to be intercepted at any time. It’s happened before, it’ll happen again. He did not expect a man to slam him over the railing of the ship and plunge in after him. Steve had lashed out with his shield, the metal slicing through the water, but it hit nothing. He kicked, again and again, but the sharp hands always returned.

The merman yanked him downwards with such force that bubbles shot out of Steve’s mouth; in an instant a clawed hand wrapped itself around his throat. Pain exploded behind his eyes when the man slammed Steve’s head against the sandy floor.

“You’ve become unbelievably annoying, Captain.” The merman’s voice rang clear in the blue. His name was Ross Sweinden, Steve remembered, one of GAIA’s packs of muscle. They had met before, only a week ago, when Ross had nearly bested him in combat. Steve was impressed, he respected Ross’s strength; the man would’ve made a worthy Avenger if only he wasn’t so eager to use brute force. “How’s about we end this?”

[[MORE]]

Steve didn’t bother to reply as his fingers twitched, aching to remove the oppressive hand. His vision was darkening, a black fuzz consuming his world. Water forced itself into his mouth, down into his lungs. A tight burn in his throat chest contrasted the chill of the blue void around him.

Ross shook him. "Don’t die on me, Steve!” His grip on Steve’s neck tightened—and then loosened.

Steve didn’t have the energy to wonder why. The black fuzz was now invading his mind, peaceful and comforting and urging him to just let go, you’ve lived long enough, Peggy is waiting, you’ve got a date. Yes, he’s given his all to this era, hasn’t he? He built up the Avengers, stopped an alien invasion, and found and liberated his friend. What more could the world, could SHIELD, want from him?

The Avengers will survive. They will take care of everyone.

Let go, Steve.

Blue filled his vision again, unusually bright. Although Steve’s vision was blurred with pain—head injury, he had to remain awake—he saw that a face was before him. It wasn’t Ross; no, a dark-haired man stared at him, a sharp-toothed but relieved smile on his face.

Steve couldn’t tear his gaze from the merman’s eyes. His irises and pupils were glowing the same blue that shined out from his strange metal suit. The werewolf was transfixed.

Too soon a smooth, featureless mask slid down over the merman’s face. He turned to the left and, his voice hosting a mechanical undertone, clicked and whistled at a companion.

In a similar mechanical suit—this one black and silver and glowing orange—was his friend. Whether it was a machine or a merperson in a metal shell, they easily and repeatedly overpowered Ross. The GAIA agent snarled and swiped but he knew he was outmatched. When the orange merman glanced at Blue, he swung in place and bolted away.

Steve really wouldn’t be surprised if Ross was the type to swear revenge.

Blue and orange, gray and black, filled his vision. Unnaturally smooth fingers and arms wrapped themselves around the joint connecting his arms to his shoulders and hoisted him up with a gentleness he only recieved from Natasha.

Above him was the moon, its form wavering erratically. Werewolves and the Moon, people thought the two had a connection. Dr. Erskine never mentioned the effects the moon had on werewolves or even human-turned-werewolves, and Steve never felt any more powerful under a full moon than he did under a crescent moon. But he prayed anyway, begging whatever—if anything—possessed the moon to heal the concussion he knew he’d have, that it wouldn’t last too long, that he’d get to go back to the surface, that Natasha and the others search for him.

_____________________________________________


Tony knew his father hated humans. Something about a human male chasing him when he was a pup. So when—and it is a when, because Father had his ways of worming secrets from their holders—Tony’s big Star was found…well, the young Princes will ensure he gets sent to the wealthiest quadrant in the human community.

For the sixth time in their hold, Star went limp. A concussion. Tony knew what those were like, to fall unconscious again and again, to sometimes forget what happened, to have the life sucked out of you at the mere flick of a tail—or leg, in Star’s case. All he and Arno could do was swim as fast as they can to Strange’s Sanctum and keep him as still as possible in their arms.

“He’s different, this Star of yours,” Arno warbled.

Tony nodded. Even in the water, humans had a particular scent to them. But Star’s taste was warped, human but not-human. “So how deep do we need to bury this secret?” Because if Father found Star he’ll know immediately that Star is in some way special, and he’ll have him tested. And if there was anything Father loved more than his own sons, it was prestige and the admiration (coughjealousycough) that came with it.

“Pretend-he-doesn’t-exist deep.” Arno led them in a dive though a cavern filled with shrimp and spiders.

“Ah, my weakness.” But Tony heard the implication in his brother’s words: We should’ve stayed home. But that only hardened Tony’s resolve to help and protect the not-human. There was something about him that lured Tony to him, something that Tony knew would be worth the hell Father will eventually put him through. As they emerged into the depths again, Tony spared Star a glance. His head was up, turning left and right as they passed swarms of bioluminescent jellyfish, but his movements were sluggish.

In the distance were the upper shelves of the Subduon, the trench Eingara was built in: the shelves of the poor, of the merchants and traders and artisans, and of the Upper Military. Piercing through the encompassing darkness were the lights, glittering and flashing red, blue, green, and yellow. The Sanctum was more attuned to the wealthy while still remaining quite a swim away; it was located right at the bottom of the trench.

“There’re going to be a lot of curious fish,” warned the elder of the brothers, angling them toward the bright lights. His gray face plate lifted, revealing a thoughtful frown. “Star still needs time to acclimate. If we take him down there, we’ll have another flounder.”

Tony nodded, lifting his own face plate. When they were young there was news of a Merrow who’d saved a human and brought them down to the depths. But even with the newfound abilities to breathe underwater and survive its bone-reaching chill, the human still had yet to adapt to the crushing depths. By the time the Merrow reached bottom of the trench, the human “looked more like a flounder.”

And Tony did not want to be the traumatized owner of a flounder.

There was a human community up on the shelf, high enough that Star would not succumb to the pressure. For now, they were Star’s best chance at survival.
As if they were sharks on the prowl the civilians cleared the way for their princes as they swept through the city, their eyes lingering on the limp not-human in their grasp. They hummed and clicked theories to one another but none were arrogant enough to intercept them. Tony prayed that they couldn’t catch Star’s scent in the water, prayed that a noble adorned with peridot, gold, and/or a rainbow of pearls wouldn’t be in the crowd.

The human living area was a time capsule, a timeline of trends that dominated the stonemasonry field mixed with the myriad of surface cultures. The first humans, chosen survivors from shipwrecks throughout the centuries, were dumped in towns of jagged and shoddy stonework. Generations passed, and new divisions were added, the stonework displaying floral and animal reliefs as well as strange geometric depictions.

Displaying a mixture of whale and dolphin reliefs and curving lines was the hospital, one of the largest buildings in western division. Like the Merrow civilians, the humans threw themselves out the way of the royals, signing to one another and pointing to Star.

Clusters of pillar coral lights bathed the inside of the reception area with kelp yellows and sky blues. The receptionist, an elderly woman, lifted her head as the princes swam up to her. Seeing that their load was limp, her eyes widened and she thrust herself from the desk. The woman pointed to a white-lit hallway on her right and swam off.

Tony and Arno followed.

The room the receptionist led them to was lit with a golden coral light that was growing downwards from the ceiling. The stony floor was carpeted with sea grass and the walls swayed with vibrant anemones and soft corals. To the left of the doorway was a wall-long counter, all its contents sorted into neat groups. In the middle of the room was a mechanical bed fashioned into a mussel shell, fitted with sealskin sheets. The princes lay Star down on the sheets, settling him on his belly.

Star blinked open his eyes. Those little windows to the sky searched the room before fixating on Tony. Confusion was written all over his youthful face.

“You’ll be safe here, I promise,” Tony assured.

title: Stephen Strange One-Shots
body:
by bodhirooks

A collection of Stephen-centric shorts!

summary: Another day, and welcome to the fourteenth post for the @sciencebrosbingo – Yep, I’ll go so fast with the bingo… But I don’t...
caption:
Another day, and welcome to the fourteenth post for the @sciencebrosbingo – Yep, I’ll go so fast with the bingo… But I don’t mind… I really need this… Following the line of things I do, they will have design and text, longer or shorter depending on the moment. All will go under the cut in the posts.

The day had come again… It wasn’t usually something that he thought too much about, but Bruce had the ridiculous idea that it was something that could help him move on for another year, so he was dragged to one day of useless talk, sentimentality and comments that only made him remember how much he missed his mother, and how much he would have liked her to meet Bruce.

-What about your father?- Bruce knew some things he had heard and read about Howard Stark, but except for a few pointed comments from Tony, he had never heard of him.
-What’s wrong with him?- Tony looked surprised at his boyfriend.
-Don’t you miss him?
-…- Tony wanted to think the answer well, instead of letting go of the first thing that crossed his mind.- No more than what I did when I was a child… And then he was alive… So, imagine the rest. Although… I would pay to see the face he would put on meeting you.
-Why? Do you think he won’t like me?
-You are brilliant, strong and incredible, besides you are not his son, I think he were going to love you. It would be with me who would have the problem.
-Then it would be me who would have a problem with him.
-Uhh, Bruce Banner getting rude with Howard Stark, change what I said before, I would PAY to see that.

blog.name: scienceboyfriendscollegeau
blog.title: I Can Hear You Sing It To Me In My Sleep
blog.description: This is going to be where I put all my ideas/headcannons/art/fanfic/mixtapes/aesthetic timelines for the 80s college AU timeline that started as an rp with a friend where Bruce and Tony meet in grad school in the late 80s. I’m open to other people contributing to this as well and maybe some rps springing from this as well! I’ve been kind of slow going getting everything together so I also just wanted to use this as a way of getting reacquainted with the fandom so this probably won’t be very organized. My main blog is stupidmonopolymoney.

question: 9, 10, 11 and 12 for Science Boyfriends
answer:
9.) Is someone multilingual? Do they teach the other one any languages?

In regular verse: I think they both know a lot of languages. I think it’s semi canon that Bruce knows several languages from being on the run so much and picking them up quickly, and I’ve adopted the common headcannon that Tony learned Italian from his mother and also picked up several languages traveling since he was young. I think they enjoy helping eachother keep up with it and talking to eachother in different languages (maybe even two different languages at the same time) and filling in the gaps of the others knowledge.

In the 80s AU: Tony still knows Italian and has picked up some things traveling in Europe; Bruce has picked up more from school than he really ever paid attention to knowing he knew and answers Tony in Spanish once without really realizing when Tony asked him something in it either when he was joking around, drunk or both.

10.) Any pets or plants?

I don’t really have any strong pet headcannons for regular or AU vers, I think Bruce likes cats and had a stray dog when he was on the run but they’re too busy to really commit to a pet and have Tony’s robot babies and Bruce has a greenhouse.

In the 80s Bruce feeds a stray cat outside his apartment and has some cacti and succulents. Tony gifts him some more and takes the cat to the vet to get her shots and everything.

11.)showers or baths? Together or separate? Bubble baths? Bubble fights? I think they both are shower people, but Bruce takes long baths when he’s down and Tony gets worried about him and offers to take a bubble bath with him and it doesn’t end up beg very sexy but a lot of fun.

12.) who talks the most? Are the comfortable with silence?

Tony talks the most when there’s a lot of people around. It’s Tony. He’s infamous for always having something to say, but I think once he gets comfortable with Bruce his constant chattering isn’t a necessity anymore and he’s a little more comfortable in the silence. Though there’s always a lot of banter. Bruce talks MORE when it’s just him and Tony and sometimes is even the more talkative one of the two. He used to be worried that silence meant someone was mad, but not with Tony, after they get close.

Thanks so much!

“It’s an Iron Duck,” Pepper explained with a yawn. “I thought it would help you with your…” she waved a hand and closed her eyes.
